Random map generation in Godot üó∫

22 April 2021

Recently I was interested in how to create random maps in Godot. The topic of creating something, like a map, by just a few lines of code has always interested me. I haven‚Äôt done anything like that yet, but I‚Äôm working on a small project where I can easily implement that.

The basic idea is simple, you create a noise map by a random noise algorithm (like the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù Perlin noise or the improved and open source version, the OpenSimplex Noise) and based on this noise the map is created. Noise algorithms are a very interesting topic in their own right, which I may delve into in the future, but for now let‚Äôs move on. In Godot, you can easily create noise using the OpenSimplexNoise class. You can use the get_image() method to create a noise image, which looks for example like this:

You probably ask yourself how do we get from this to a map? Well, as mentioned the basic idea is simple, for each pixel we have now a float value between 0 and 1. One can now assign for each partial range from 0 to 1 (e.g. 0.25 to 0.50) a specific tile (e.g. grass).

Side Note: For my project I used a tileset from kenney.nl, which is very good for prototyping.

This means, you take the noise image, loop through each pixel and based on the value of this pixel you assign a specific tile. This is the basic idea, you can check a playable example (works best on desktop) on my itch.io page, or click the link down below. I also have the source code on my GitHub page check Evolution as this example is a part of a small project I‚Äôm working on.
